docs.title: Welcome to Alexandria Archives
docs.text:
This is a consolidated guide for various technical setups mostly for me, to make sure it's stored somewher, as technical work like this is not always intuitive and sometimes you will face an issue which is not easily solved. These are currently including:

  • Setting up markdown projects like this one
  • Setting up Switch emulation using Yuzu, including:
    • Setting up Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom (TotK) and Breath of the Wild (BotW)
    • Optimizing both TotK and BotW with settings or tools
    • Installing and configuring mods

docs.title: Setting Up MkDocs with Material
docs.text: This section will guide you through setting up MkDocs with the Material theme. MkDocs is a static site generator that's geared towards project documentation.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text: Make sure you have Python installed. You can download it from the official Python website.

docs.title: Step-by-Step Setup
docs.text:
1. Create a Virtual Environment

It's a good practice to use a virtual environment to manage your project's dependencies. Here are the commands to create and activate a virtual environment:

python -m venv venv

  1. Activate the Virtual Environment

  2. On Windows:

    .\venv\Scripts\activate

  3. On macOS and Linux:

    source venv/bin/activate

  4. Install MkDocs and MkDocs-Material

With your virtual environment activated, install MkDocs and the Material theme:

pip install mkdocs mkdocs-material
  1. Create a New MkDocs Project

Initialize a new MkDocs project using the following command:

mkdocs new my-project
cd my-project
  1. Edit mkdocs.yml to Use the Material Theme

Open the mkdocs.yml file in your project directory and modify it to use the Material theme:

site_name: My Project
theme:
  name: material
  1. Serve the Documentation Locally

To preview your documentation locally, use the serve command:

mkdocs serve

Open your browser and navigate to http://127.0.0.1:8000/ to see your MkDocs site in action.

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text: With these steps, you have successfully set up MkDocs with the Material theme. You can now start writing your project documentation and use the MkDocs server to preview your changes in real-time.

docs.title: Plain codeblock
docs.text:
A plain codeblock:

Some code here
def myfunction()
// some comment

docs.title: Code for a specific language
docs.text:
Some more code with the py at the start:

import tensorflow as tf
def whatever()

docs.title: With a title
With line numbers
docs.text:
def bubble_sort(items):
    for i in range(len(items)):
        for j in range(len(items) - 1 - i):
            if items[j] > items[j + 1]:
                items[j], items[j + 1] = items[j + 1], items[j]

docs.title: Highlighting lines
docs.text:
def bubble_sort(items):
    for i in range(len(items)):
        for j in range(len(items) - 1 - i):
            if items[j] > items[j + 1]:
                items[j], items[j + 1] = items[j + 1], items[j]
